image.altText: a man and a woman sitting at a school desk talking and smiling with students

items.synopsis: More than 1,000 temporary public school teachers are expected to be made permanent by term 3, in what the NSW government says is the first stage of its promised 10,000 conversions.

title.children: NSW government moves on election promise to make temporary public school teachers permanent

image.altText: Jess Micallef stands near turf farm paddock under paddock

items.synopsis: NSW Farmers say a process to protect people and property in flood-prone areas is long overdue, especially after the deadly devastation in the Northern Rivers last year.

title.children: Flood-prone communities demand better planning to protect life and property

image.altText: A chef holds up plates of food.

items.synopsis: Scottish-born Jock Zonfrillo — who died in Melbourne — is being remembered as an "incredible chef" who was loved in and outside of the kitchen.

title.children: Jock Zonfrillo remembered as an 'incredible chef' and influential member of Australia's culinary landscape

image.altText: An African lady smiling in her new social housing residence

items.synopsis: The Parliamentary Budget Office warns phasing out property tax breaks may "trigger a significant economic shock". That's why next week's budget is more focused on increasing the supply of housing rather than trying to make housing affordable by reducing house prices.

title.children: Phasing out property tax breaks could save $74b but it also could create 'significant economic shock'

image.altText: Two women sit beside each other on a bench. One woman has her arm around the other's shoulders.

items.synopsis: Desley Ketchup believes her son might still be alive if police had let her or his siblings speak to him during a siege. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this article contains images and names of people who have died.

title.children: Family of man shot dead by police question why they weren't called in to help

image.altText: Derek Balogh

items.synopsis: He calls himself an advocate, charges for advice on fines and council rates and makes incredible claims about his success in courtrooms around Australia. But Derek Balogh has left a trail of failed cases in his wake.

title.children: This man advises his clients that elections, rates and mortgages are invalid

image.altText: Raeleen sits with her three grandkids - a little girl wearing pink and two boys in T-shirts - out the front of their house.

items.synopsis: Nearly three quarters of Australians expect child poverty to worsen this year and say cost-of-living pressures are having a greater impact than the pandemic, according to a long-running survey released exclusively to ABC News.

title.children: Selling the furniture and couch-surfing: Families forced to make 'impossible' decisions amid fears inflation crisis hitting kids

image.altText: Illustration of a woman looking at the reflection of her face in red wine

items.synopsis: Clare started using alcohol to feel better when life became difficult. She almost lost everything she cared about but eventually she found her way back to happiness.

title.children: 'The first three weeks were brutal': Clare went into rehab just as lockdown kicked in 2020, but she stuck with it

image.altText: A selfie of a woman and man in beanie in front of blue van

items.synopsis: Rachel Lehmann Ware and her husband, Duncan, made a chaotic escape from Ukraine with their three cats after the Russian invasion last year. Now the Tasmanian teachers have returned to Kyiv, where lessons are often taught in an air raid shelter.

title.children: A year ago, this Australian couple fled Ukraine with their three cats. Now they're back in Kyiv

image.altText: Smoke rises from buildings in the city of Khartoum, where a man can be seen in the foreground walking on the ground.

items.synopsis: It is estimated some 73,000 people have already fled to Sudan's neighbouring countries.

title.children: Sudan humanitarian crisis turning into a 'full-blown catastrophe', UN says

image.altText: Close up of woman exhaling while vaping.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: A ban on non-prescription vapes, a Texas gunman on the run, and TV props up for auction. Catch up with The Loop

schema.headline: The Loop live: Non-prescription vapes to be banned, the search for a Texas gunman enters its third day, and historic TV props up for auction

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Aerosmith announce farewell tour, but no Australian dates
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: US rockers Aerosmith have announced their farewell tour after 50-plus years together, but Australia has missed out (so far). The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame band have announced the dates for their Peace Out farewell tour, which begins in September and includes 40 shows across the US and Canada. "I think it's about time," guitarist Joe Perry said in an interview with The Associated Press. Perry believes the time to say goodbye is now, especially with every founding band member over the age of 70. Frontman Steven Tyler, 75, is the oldest in the group. "It's kind of a chance to celebrate the 50 years we've been out here," Perry said. "You never know how much longer everybody's going to be healthy to do this. … It's been a while since we've actually done a real tour. We did that run in Vegas, which was great. It was fun, but (we're) kind of anxious to get back on the road."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ban on non-prescription vapes to be announced today
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Health Minister Mark Butler is expected to today unveil a plan to stamp out the growing black market for illegal vaping. The Government will allocate $234 million dollars in next week's budget to reduce harm caused by tobacco and vaping products, including to stop the importation of non-prescription vapes. Under the changes, all general practitioners will be able to prescribe flavour-free, plain packaged vapes to patients working to quit smoking. Speaking on Q & A last night, Butler said easy access to vapes had created a new generation of nicotine addicts. "This is now the number one behavioural issue in high schools and it's rapidly becoming a serious behavioural issue in primary schools," he said. "This is a very serious problem we're facing and it has exploded over the last few years. While we were focused on the pandemic, it has utterly exploded and we've got to deal with it now." Butler is expected to further detail the government's plans during a speech at the National Press Club from 12:30pm today .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Search for Texas gunman who killed five neighbours enters third day
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The search for a gunman who fatally shot five neighbours with an AR-style rifle in the US state of Texas has entered a third day, after authorities expanded their search over the weekend while acknowledging they had little sense of the killer's possible whereabouts. On Monday, a heavy presence of police converged in an area where police had reported a possible sighting of the suspect, but later 38-year-old Francisco Oropeza wasn't found despite a search by officers, scent-tracking dogs and aerial police. The false alarm was one of the first times since Friday's shooting in the rural town of Cleveland that authorities had announced a possible sighting of Oropeza. By Sunday evening, authorities said more than 250 officers from multiple jurisdictions had joined the search, and Texas Governor Greg Abbott put up $US50,000 ($75,000) in reward money for tips leading to Oropeza's capture. "I can tell you right now, we have zero leads," said James Smith, the FBI special agent in charge.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: News Australia is searching for: Met Gala 2023
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Celebrities are hitting up New York City's Metropolitan Museum of Art today for the annual charity night and fashion event known as the Met Gala. This year's theme is Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, paying tribute to the German fashion designer who died in 2019 — a theme which has proven to be controversial. Today's red carpet is expected to start live streaming at 8am AEST on Vogue's social media accounts. We will also be live blogging the event in a separate blog, so keep an eye out for that. You can read more about this year's Met Gala at the link below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One more thing: Props from shows like Breaking Bad, Cheers and I Dream of Jeannie are up for auction
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you've ever wanted to own a piece of television history, keep your eye out for a major auction coming up in the US from collector James Comisar. A number of props, sets and costumes from beloved television shows will be sold in early June — from the bar where Sam Malone greeted customers on Cheers, to the pink outfit Barbara Eden wore in I Dream of Jeannie, to props used on the set of Breaking Bad. Other items up for auction include a tunic worn by Superman in the 1950s TV series, barware from Mad Men, and costumes from Star Trek. Comisar had dreamed of creating a museum to house his collection, but when that failed to come together, he decided it was time the items leave the temperature-controlled warehouses where he's been caring for them. "I just decided these pieces should go back to the fans and let them enjoy them and then when that good day comes when a TV museum is effectuated, these pieces will be well cared for in the hands of passionate fans and collectors," he said.

"You never know how much longer everybody's going to be healthy to do this. … It's been a while since we've actually done a real tour. We did that run in Vegas, which was great. It was fun, but (we're) kind of anxious to get back on the road."

"I think it's about time," guitarist Joe Perry said in an interview with The Associated Press.

The Government will allocate $234 million dollars in next week's budget to reduce harm caused by tobacco and vaping products, including to stop the importation of non-prescription vapes. Butler is expected to further detail the government's plans during a speech at the National Press Club from 12:30pm today .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The search for a gunman who fatally shot five neighbours with an AR-style rifle in the US state of Texas has entered a third day, after authorities expanded their search over the weekend while acknowledging they had little sense of the killer's possible whereabouts. On Monday, a heavy presence of police converged in an area where police had reported a possible sighting of the suspect, but later 38-year-old Francisco Oropeza wasn't found despite a search by officers, scent-tracking dogs and aerial police. The false alarm was one of the first times since Friday's shooting in the rural town of Cleveland that authorities had announced a possible sighting of Oropeza. By Sunday evening, authorities said more than 250 officers from multiple jurisdictions had joined the search, and Texas Governor Greg Abbott put up $US50,000 ($75,000) in reward money for tips leading to Oropeza's capture. "I can tell you right now, we have zero leads," said James Smith, the FBI special agent in charge.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Celebrities are hitting up New York City's Metropolitan Museum of Art today for the annual charity night and fashion event known as the Met Gala. This year's theme is Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, paying tribute to the German fashion designer who died in 2019 — a theme which has proven to be controversial. Today's red carpet is expected to start live streaming at 8am AEST on Vogue's social media accounts. We will also be live blogging the event in a separate blog, so keep an eye out for that. You can read more about this year's Met Gala at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: News Australia is searching for: Met Gala 2023

featuredLink.title: It's the event that costs $50,000 for a ticket. Here's when the Met Gala is and who's expected to show

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've ever wanted to own a piece of television history, keep your eye out for a major auction coming up in the US from collector James Comisar. A number of props, sets and costumes from beloved television shows will be sold in early June — from the bar where Sam Malone greeted customers on Cheers, to the pink outfit Barbara Eden wore in I Dream of Jeannie, to props used on the set of Breaking Bad. Other items up for auction include a tunic worn by Superman in the 1950s TV series, barware from Mad Men, and costumes from Star Trek. Comisar had dreamed of creating a museum to house his collection, but when that failed to come together, he decided it was time the items leave the temperature-controlled warehouses where he's been caring for them. "I just decided these pieces should go back to the fans and let them enjoy them and then when that good day comes when a TV museum is effectuated, these pieces will be well cared for in the hands of passionate fans and collectors," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One more thing: Props from shows like Breaking Bad, Cheers and I Dream of Jeannie are up for auction

props.alt: Gloves next to a large scale on a bench. On the scale is a plastic ziplock bag containing pills. Beakers are placed near the scale

image.altText: Talou Kesia

items.synopsis: After a string of shark attacks, New Caledonia's government closed Nouméa's beaches for a year. But locals say it has gone too far.

title.children: Nouméa is an island paradise — but for the next year you're not allowed to swim

image.altText: Child's hand clasping adult male finger, close up.

items.synopsis: A former UK crime analyst was so stunned by the prevalence of child sexual abuse in Australia that he studied perpetrators' character traits in an effort to better educate authorities and parents.

title.children: Crime analyst breaks down character traits of 'most prolific' child sex offenders in effort to protect vulnerable

image.altText: A wooden thrown with a stone placed under the seat.

items.synopsis: An ancient and controversial block of stone has made the journey from Edinburgh Castle to London for the coronation of King Charles III.

title.children: What is the Stone of Destiny and why is it needed for the King's coronation?

image.altText: A tattooed middle-aged white man wearing a grey polo shirt, jeans and a bandanna sits in front of motel wall.

items.synopsis: Almost three months after a Norfolk Southern train derailment blackened the skies and sent residents fleeing, residents of East Palestine, Ohio say they are still unsure how to move on.

title.children: 'No idea how long we can continue': East Palestine families still living in limbo, months after fiery train wreck

image.altText: A drone shot of a regional suburb with houses and trees and playgrounds

items.synopsis: Against all logic and decades of previous experience, housing prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned the corner, writes Ian Verrender. This isn't supposed to be happening.

title.children: Perfect storm brewing for housing market and it could make buying your own home a pipedream

image.altText: A tractor at sunset, working in the paddock.

items.synopsis: As natural disasters continue to grow, farmers are paying more for insurance, with premiums increasing 20 to 40 per cent.

title.children: Higher insurance premiums for farmers as natural disasters, inflation bite

image.altText: A sign sits outside Launceston General Hospital.

items.synopsis: A coroner lashes the Launceston General Hospital for not following its procedures and causing delays in diagnosing a baby's bowel obstruction, saying it was the "difference between her survival and death".

title.children: Baby with bowel obstruction died after hospital's failures, coroner finds

image.altText: A fire burns beyond a mountain range.

items.synopsis: The new system would let the government instantly message all mobiles in a defined area — stopping them from being overlooked or dismissed by those in danger.

title.children: 'Every second is critical': Major upgrade to national emergency messages to receive more than $10m

image.altText: A car billows with fire and thick, black smoke in a parking lot during protests in France.

items.synopsis: May Day traditionally sees large rallies, but unions are expecting hundreds of thousands of people to turn out this year as anger against pension reform continues.

title.children: Violence and chaos erupt at the May Day labour union march in Paris

image.altText: a trader wearing glasses works at the post where First Republic stock is traded at the NYSE

items.synopsis: US regional bank First Republic had a little more than $301 billion worth of assets and around 7,000 employees.

title.children: US authorities 'auction' First Republic Bank after second biggest bank failure in history

image.altText: a man with a bleeding mouth on a sports field

items.synopsis: The man accused of punching and kicking a soccer referee in the head after a Friday night match in Sydney is refused bail.

title.children: Soccer spectator accused of punching out teeth of referee in 'outrageous attack' refused bail

image.altText: A grey crocodile with a pointed beak inside a bright purple plastic bin.

items.synopsis: A metre-long female crocodile, believed to be an escaped or dumped pet, was found jammed against a fence by Umina home owners while doing some yard work on Sunday.

title.children: 'Thought it was a toy:' Metre-long croc found in backyard of NSW Central Coast home

image.altText: a young woman walking outdoors after leaving a court house

items.synopsis: The daughter of a former deputy commissioner at the Australian Tax Office is sentenced to a maximum of eight years in prison for her role in a $105 million tax fraud conspiracy.

title.children: Lauren Cranston jailed for eight years over one of Australia's biggest tax frauds

image.altText: A young man in blue overalls stands with his hands on his hips as he watches a derailed train carriage burn.

items.synopsis: Pictures shared on social media show several train carriages lying on their side and dark grey smoke billowing into the air at the site of the derailment, in the Bryansk region.

title.children: Russian freight train derails after being hit by explosive device, governor says

image.altText: A jellyfish inside a glass jar in a dark room

items.synopsis: Marine scientists say it is unlikely the jellyfish are "the" lethal tropical variety, but note samples found off Cronulla feature traits from both the toxic and non-toxic varieties.

title.children: Mystery box jellyfish found off Sydney beach being investigated by scientists

image.altText: Canberra Raiders NRL players leap on teammates in celebration of a win, as a Dolphins player is obscured in the background.

items.synopsis: The NRL's Graham Annesley says officials missed a Canberra knock-on in the lead-up to their match-winning golden point field goal against the Dolphins.

title.children: NRL concedes error on crucial golden point call

image.altText: A man in a red Adventure Kokoda t-shirt speaking into a walkie talkie

items.synopsis: A major route into the Kokoda Track in Papua New Guinea's Central Province appears to be blockaded, amid a feud between a trekking operator and the track's managing authority.

title.children: Major route into the Kokoda track appears to have been blockaded amid tour operator feud

image.altText: A group of four people standing in front of saluting paramedics, clearly overwhelmed with emotion.

items.synopsis: Steven Tougher's pregnant wife is among those who pay tribute to the 29-year-old at an emotional service in Wollongong.

title.children: 'They will forever know their dad was a hero': 1,000 mourners farewell slain NSW paramedic

image.altText: A man raises a hand while performing a dance move.

items.synopsis: Ian Smith, the husband of former Democrats leader Natasha Stott Despoja, busted out the move in front of an audience including Julie Bishop, Malcolm Turnbull and Hollywood A-listers Kate Beckinsale, Sienna Miller and Kate Moss at a gala dinner in New York last week.

title.children: 'The worm goes global': Rita Ora wowed by Adelaide lobbyist's dancefloor moves

image.altText: An animation of Earth being orbited by hundreds of objects.

items.synopsis: For millennia humans have gazed up at the wonder of the night sky, but what we can see is rapidly changing because of our quest to be connected.

title.children: Earth's orbit is becoming more crowded and our window to the universe is at stake
